claim: If A was born before B, then A is older than B

supporting.text: Age is determined by the chronological order of birth, so if A was born before B, A has existed for a longer period of time.

attacks.text: Age is determined by the chronological order of birth, so if A was born before B, A has existed for a longer period of time.
In cases of time dilation or relativistic effects (e.g., near a black hole), A could be born before B in one reference frame but not in another, making age comparison non-trivial.
If A was born prematurely and B was born post-term, biological age might not align with chronological age.
Relativistic effects are negligible in everyday human contexts, so they don't invalidate the general rule for practical purposes.
Biological age variations due to prematurity are exceptions and don't override the standard definition of age based on birth order.

supporting.text: The concept of age is based on the time elapsed since birth, making the person born earlier older by definition.

attacks.text: The concept of age is based on the time elapsed since birth, making the person born earlier older by definition.
In relativistic physics, time dilation means that two observers moving at different velocities may disagree on the order of events, including birth order.
Time dilation effects are negligible at human-scale velocities and timescales, making this irrelevant for practical age comparisons.
If A was born just before midnight and B just after in different time zones, their local dates might falsely suggest A is older when they're effectively twins.
Legal and biological age definitions universally use absolute time (e.g., UTC) rather than local time to resolve such edge cases.

supporting.text: In all standard age calculations, the individual born first is considered older than the one born later.

attacks.text: In all standard age calculations, the individual born first is considered older than the one born later.
In some cultures, age is calculated differently, such as counting time in the womb or considering everyone born in the same year as the same age.
Even in cultures with alternative age calculations, standard international age calculations still apply for legal and official purposes.
Time zone differences can result in cases where A is born before B in local time but after B in UTC, creating ambiguity in age ordering.
Standard age calculations typically use a consistent time reference (e.g., UTC) to resolve time zone ambiguities.

supporting.text: Legal and biological definitions of age rely on birth dates, confirming that earlier birth means greater age.

attacks.text: Legal and biological definitions of age rely on birth dates, confirming that earlier birth means greater age.
In some cultures, age is counted from conception or another milestone, not birth, making birth date alone insufficient for age comparison.
Modern legal systems universally standardize age calculation from birth date, overriding cultural variations in age reckoning.
Relativity theory shows time is not absolute, so birth order may not correspond to age difference for observers in different reference frames.
Relativistic effects are negligible in human-scale timekeeping, and legal age definitions assume Newtonian time.
